title: Principles of Musical Structure Building: Theory, Computation, and Cognition
descriptions:
The "Principles of Musical Structure Building: Theory, Computation, and Cognition" grant proposal aims to advance our understanding of human cognition by focusing on complex auditory sequences and syntactic structures in music perception. The project encompasses three key strands: theoretical, computational, and experimental. 

The theoretical strand seeks to develop a novel unified theory of musical syntax that surpasses context-free complexity, with a specific focus on harmonic structure and voice leading constraints. Current approaches are limited to harmonic syntax and rely on tree-based context-free grammars, highlighting the need for a more comprehensive framework.

The computational aspect of the project involves compiling and publishing a large corpus of digitized syntactic analyses, implementing a unified syntax theory based on generalized parsing and graph grammars, and evaluating these through analytical corpus-based training and assessment.

Finally, the experimental strand aims to test specific predictions about mental representations of musical structure, focusing on nonlocal dependency relations, learnability, revision, and tension. By bridging theoretical, computational, and experimental domains, this project will make significant contributions to the fields of music cognition and cognitive sciences, shedding light on the intricate processes involved in perceiving and understanding musical structures.
